problem.p: Block 1 falls, immediately before the collision
External Interactions: the block and the string resulting in a force of tension T
Internal Interactions: block 1 and Earth, the work done by this force is treated as a potential energy
Physical Principle: Mechanical Energy and Work

Although there is an external force, cause by the tension, acting on Block 1, the force is constantly directed perpendicular to the motion of the block, so it does not do any work. This means that mechanical energy is conserved in the Block 1 + Earth system as the block swings down to reach the vertical position.
External interactions: the blocks with the Earth and with the surface. There is no friction, therefore the net external force is zero.

Because the net force is zero , there is no external impulse and the momentum is constant during the collision. Conservation of momentum can be used to find the velocity of Block 2 immediately after the collision.
(You cannot use conservation of kinetic energy to find the velocity of Block 2 immediately after the collision because energy is lost during the collision.
Block 2 sliding along the track between points B and C.
External Interactions: block 2 and the track. Assuming no friction, the resulting force is a normal force N.
Internal Interactions: block 2 and the Earth. This interaction is represented by the gravitational potential energy.

There are not internal and non-conservative forces and because the external force, N, is normal to the displacement its work is zero, so the mechanical energy is constant. This can be used to find the height H at which Block 2 falls off of the path.
